question: what are people saying about generative AI, what is the latest breaking news on it

highlights: Who wants to label 50 million cat pictures? Okay, a few people probably — but who wants to label 50 million pictures of common fruits and vegetables? Currently some of the most promising AI systems are what are called self-supervised: models that can work from large quantities of unlabeled data, like books or video of people interacting, and build their own structured understanding of what the rules are of the system.

A picture of a cat with the cat part labeled, a conversation with the speakers and words transcribed, etc. But that approach is no longer in vogue as researchers found that it was no longer feasible to manually create databases of the sizes needed to train next-gen AIs. Who wants to label 50 million cat pictures?
summaries.summary: Meta researchers are developing a versatile AI, named data2vec, capable of learning autonomously across different domains such as speech, text, and visuals without needing labeled data. Traditional AI training methods rely on vast amounts of labeled examples, a process deemed unfeasible for next-gen AI due to the sheer volume required. Data2vec, a self-supervised model, learns from unlabeled data, inferring rules and structures similarly to human learning. It has shown competitive or superior performance compared to specialized models in tests, aiming to reduce reliance on labeled data significantly. This research, still in early stages, could lead to more generalized AI systems, understanding the world through a combination of senses. The data2vec framework and some pretrained models are open source, available for further development.

highlights: Sometimes you have to build something with 175 billion parameters to say, well, maybe we can do this with 10 billion.” A good question-answering AI isn’t just good for party tricks, but is central to things like voice-powered search. A local model that can answer simple questions quickly and correctly without consulting outside sources is fundamentally valuable, and it’s unlikely your Amazon Echo is going to run GPT-3 — it would be like buying a semi truck to go to the grocery store with.

For instance, he said, asking “When did Tom Hanks land on the moon?” GPT-3 says 1995, since that’s when the film Apollo 13 came out. But Macaw correctly notes that, as far as we know, Tom Hanks has in fact never been to the moon.  AI2 has published a collection of examples (“demo” is probably too strong a word) that illustrate the difference, with Macaw often providing the better answer to a variety of tricky and not-so-tricky questions.
summaries.summary: The Allen Institute for AI (AI2) has developed Macaw, an AI model that rivals OpenAI's GPT-3 in question-answering capabilities but is significantly more efficient, being only a tenth the size of GPT-3's 175 billion parameters. Macaw excels in providing accurate answers to a range of questions, showcasing a better grasp of common sense compared to GPT-3. For example, Macaw correctly identifies that Tom Hanks has never been to the moon, a question that trips up GPT-3. Despite its efficiency and accuracy, Macaw still has limitations, such as mistakenly believing snakes have legs. AI2's head, Oren Etzioni, emphasizes that Macaw is not intended to replace GPT-3 but to advance research in language generation and understanding. Macaw's development demonstrates that significant achievements in AI can be accomplished with less data, challenging the notion that larger models are always better. Macaw is open source, inviting further

highlights: “But if you apply cause and effect techniques to understand the mechanics of how different bodies work, you can understand more of the true nature of how one part has an impact on another.” Considering all of the variables that might be involved, it’s the kind of big data problem that’s nearly impossible for a human, or even a team of humans, to compute, but is table stakes for a computer to work through. While it is not a cure for cancer, this kind of work is a significant step toward starting to consider different treatments tailored to the many permutations involved.

“Human bodies are complex systems, and so applying basic AI paradigms you can find any pattern you want, correlations of any sort, and you are not getting anywhere,” Darko Matovski, the CEO and founder of the startup, said in an interview. “But if you apply cause and effect techniques to understand the mechanics of how different bodies work, you can understand more of the true nature of how one part has an impact on another.” Considering all of the variables that might be involved, it’s the kind of big data problem that’s nearly impossible for a human, or even a team of humans, to compute, but is table stakes for a computer to work through.
summaries.summary: CausaLens, a startup specializing in causal inference AI, has secured $45 million in funding to enhance AI systems with cause-and-effect reasoning, aiming to mimic human understanding. The London-based company, valued at around $250 million, has grown its revenue by 500% since emerging from stealth a year ago. The funding round, led by Dorilton Ventures and Molten Ventures, with participation from previous and new backers, will support causaLens's no-code tool designed for non-data scientists. The technology is already being used across healthcare, financial services, and government sectors to improve decision-making and outcomes. For instance, the Mayo Clinic employs causaLens to identify cancer biomarkers, while a major public health agency utilized it to strategize COVID-19 vaccination efforts. Financial services and hedge funds leverage the technology for bias-free loan evaluations and market trend analysis, respectively. CausaLens is also exploring applications in autonomous transportation, addressing the challenge of integrating human-like reasoning into AI. The company's

“It’s just so much goddamned stress.”

There, in an office just in from the garage, he opened a computer program called PioSOLVER, one of

Only Davies called.

The dealer laid out a king, four and five, all clubs, giving Davies a straight draw. Smith checked (bet nothing). Davies bet.
summaries.summary: In November, during the World Series of Poker Super High Roller event in Las Vegas, professional poker player Seth Davies demonstrated high-stakes strategy with a bluff that secured him a significant pot. With an entry fee of $250,000, the tournament attracted the world's elite, playing for substantial sums. Davies, after a tense hand against Dan Smith, pushed all-in with nothing, successfully bluffing Smith into folding. This move, risking his entire tournament position, highlighted the psychological warfare inherent in poker. Davies later analyzed the hand using PioSOLVER, a tool that underscores the blend of skill, strategy, and technology in modern poker.

summaries.summary: The New York Times is offering a digital subscription at an introductory rate of $4 every 4 weeks for the first year, after which the rate increases to $17 every 4 weeks. This offer is not available to current subscribers and excludes access to the print edition, NYTimes Games, Cooking, Wirecutter, and The Athletic. Subscriptions auto-renew until canceled, with cancellation effective at the end of the current billing period. Taxes may apply, and offer terms are subject to change. This subscription allows unlimited article access on The Times' website.

highlights: ) These numbers are all very impressive, but they do invite the question: what is an AI supercomputer anyway? And how does it compare to what we usually think of as supercomputers — vast machines deployed by universities and governments to crunch numbers in complex domains like space, nuclear physics, and climate change? The two types of systems, known as high-performance computers or HPCs, are certainly more similar than they are different.

“HPC vendors typically quote performance numbers that indicate the absolute fastest their machine can run. We call that the theoretical peak performance,” says Sorensen. “However, the real measure of a good system design is one that can run fast on the jobs they are designed to do.
summaries.summary: Meta, led by CEO Mark Zuckerberg, announced the development of the AI Research SuperCluster (RSC), poised to become the world's fastest AI supercomputer by mid-2022. RSC, already operational in its first phase with 760 Nvidia GGX A100 systems and 6,080 GPUs, will expand to 16,000 GPUs in its second phase, enhancing Meta's AI capabilities across content moderation, augmented reality, and the metaverse. Unlike traditional supercomputers, AI supercomputers like RSC focus on machine learning with less emphasis on calculation accuracy, allowing for faster data processing with 32-bit or 16-bit floating-point operations. This distinction underscores the evolving landscape of high-performance computing, emphasizing practical application over theoretical peak performance. Meta's initiative reflects the growing importance of AI research in tech, competing with Microsoft and Nvidia in the race to harness AI's potential for future technologies.

highlights: (They also mention that other tools have been built that perform the same task. ) Dani told The Verge that tl;dr papers “was designed to be an experiment to see if we can make learning about science a little easier, more fun, and engaging.” He says: “I appreciate all of the attention the app has received and thank all of the people who have tried it out [but] given this was always intended to be an educational project, I plan to sunset tl;dr papers in the coming days to focus on exploring new things.”

) Dani told The Verge that tl;dr papers “was designed to be an experiment to see if we can make learning about science a little easier, more fun, and engaging.” He says: “I appreciate all of the attention the app has received and thank all of the people who have tried it out [but] given this was always intended to be an educational project, I plan to sunset tl;dr papers in the coming days to focus on exploring new things.”
summaries.summary: tl;dr papers, an AI project started by Yash Dani and Cindy Wu, simplifies scientific papers to make them understandable even to a seven-year-old, gaining viral attention on Twitter among academics. Utilizing GPT-3, it condenses abstracts into child-like summaries, sometimes inaccurately but often with surprising clarity, like summarizing the "glass cliff" concept as a bad place for women leaders. Critics highlight its potential as a teaching tool and creativity catalyst despite limitations, including inaccuracies and ethical concerns. Despite its popularity, the creators plan to sunset the project, emphasizing its role as an educational experiment rather than a permanent service.

highlights: Waymo is seeking to keep private information about how it handles certain autonomous vehicle emergencies  Waymo is seeking to keep private information about how it handles certain autonomous vehicle emergencies, how it responds when its vehicles attempt to drive somewhere they are not intended to go, and how they handle steep hills or tight curves. Waymo is currently testing some of its vehicles in downtown San Francisco, where it is permitted to operate fully driverless cars without safety drivers. The lawsuit, which was filed in Sacramento County Superior Court last week, argues that releasing this information to the public would put Waymo at a competitive disadvantage.

The suit stems from a public records request to the DMV from an unidentified party  The suit stems from a public records request to the DMV from an unidentified party seeking Waymo’s application for a permit to operate driverless cars on public roads. Before complying with the request, the DMV allowed Waymo to redact certain details. The individual seeking the information challenged the redactions, and the DMV advised Waymo to seek an injunction through a lawsuit if it wanted to block that challenge.
summaries.summary: Waymo, an autonomous vehicle company owned by Alphabet, has filed a lawsuit against the California Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) to prevent the public release of driverless car crash data, arguing it constitutes a trade secret. The lawsuit, reported by Business Insider and the Los Angeles Times, was filed in Sacramento County Superior Court. Waymo contends that disclosing how it handles autonomous vehicle emergencies and navigates complex driving scenarios could disadvantage it competitively and deter industry investment. The dispute arose from a public records request, with Waymo seeking to redact certain details. Despite its stance on this issue, Waymo has previously shared extensive data on its safety performance and testing, including a report on 6.1 million miles of driving data. The company emphasizes its commitment to transparency while protecting sensitive information. The DMV has not commented on the ongoing litigation.

highlights: And 99.9 percent of the time, it works: It correctly concludes that the word suit is part of a judge’s email to counsel. The other 0.1 percent of the time, the AI snaps. It misidentifies a diving suit as a lawyerly conversation, tightening the loop to exclude the actual truth and plunging into an ocean that it thinks is a courtroom.

This is “closing the circle.” It leverages big data to tighten a circumference of possibilities to a single dot. And 99.9 percent of the time, it works: It correctly concludes that the word suit is part of a judge’s email to counsel. The other 0.1 percent of the time, the AI snaps.
summaries.summary: Generative AI, while advancing rapidly, is encountering significant challenges due to its inability to handle ambiguity and volatility in real-world data. This limitation not only causes AI systems to malfunction—resulting in accidents and errors—but also pressures society to conform to more predictable and quantifiable behaviors, stifling human creativity and resilience. The article advocates for a paradigm shift towards developing "antifragile" AI, which, unlike current systems that prioritize optimization and data accumulation, would thrive on chaos and improve from setbacks. This approach involves rethinking AI's design to embrace human-like qualities of adaptability, creativity, and the ability to operate with incomplete information. By moving away from the pursuit of perfect accuracy and embracing a model that values resilience and adequacy, AI can become a more reliable and complementary tool to human intelligence. The article suggests practical steps for integrating antifragility into AI, including designing systems that can handle ambiguity, foster creativity, and improve AI-human collaboration. These changes aim to create AI that

highlights: Both are based on machine learning algorithms honed to predict protein structures by training on a collection of more than 100,000 known structures. The next month, DeepMind published details of its own work and released AlphaFold for anyone to use. Suddenly, the world had two ways to predict protein structures.

They spit out a single static structure for a protein, and don’t capture the flexes and wiggles that take place when it interacts with other molecules. The algorithms were trained on databases of known structures, which are more reflective of those easiest to map experimentally rather than the full diversity of nature. Kresten Lindorff-Larsen, a professor at the University of Copenhagen, predicts the algorithms will be used more frequently and will be useful, but says, “We also as a field need to learn better when these methods fail.”
summaries.summary: The advent of AI in molecular biology, particularly with the emergence of Omicron's spike protein, marks a significant shift in the field. Alphabet's DeepMind and the University of Washington introduced software capable of predicting protein structures, a development that arrived just before Omicron's emergence. Although these tools weren't initially designed for analyzing mutations like those in Omicron, they represent a major leap forward, enabling researchers like Ford to explore protein predictions. This has sparked a change in how biologists approach their work, with AI predictions becoming increasingly integral to research, including future disease outbreaks. Despite skepticism from some quarters, the ability to predict protein structures is seen as transformative, aiding in everything from evolutionary studies to drug discovery. Traditional methods of determining protein structures are complex and labor-intensive, involving techniques like x-ray crystallography and electron microscopy. The breakthrough by DeepMind's AlphaFold, which accurately predicted protein structures, was hailed as a solution to a decades-old problem, despite initial frustrations over the

highlights: Is it when it is physically printed? Is it when the image is 2D? Is it when it is not interactive?
Is it when the image is 2D? Is it when it is not interactive? Is it the object or the information?
summaries.summary: In Dhaka, post-1971 Bangladesh liberation war, film scarcity and a broken camera halted family photography, leaving a gap in personal history until digital advancements. The transition from analog to digital photography challenges traditional definitions, questioning the essence of a photograph in the era of machine vision and AI. Analog captures physical reality through chemical reactions, while digital translates light into data, offering manipulation ease. Artists like Richard Mosse and Robert Dash expand beyond visible light, capturing unseen aspects of reality, pushing the boundaries of image capture and processing. AI further advances image processing, generating portraits from facial recognition models, illustrating the evolving relationship between technology and photography, and its impact on how we perceive and document reality.

highlights: Through years of previous experience, human meteorologists continue to beat machine learning algorithms. Humans are also significantly better at predicting dangerous weather events such as serious storms including the tornados that tore through the Midwest in early December killing more than 60 people. Forecasters can often spot these tornadoes by looking for their signatures on radar.

These are variations that weather prediction algorithms don’t take into account. Using this information, Devanas and his team were able to see if there was a correlation between certain actors and a higher risk of waterspouts. These observations were compared to a modeled probability index that indicates whether waterspouts are likely and found that with the right combination of atmosphere measurements, the human forecast successfully “outperformed” the algorithmic model in every metric for predicting waterspouts.
summaries.summary: Despite significant advancements in AI and billions invested in weather prediction technology, including the development of sophisticated algorithms and the launch of high-resolution satellites like GOES-16 and -17, human meteorologists continue to outperform AI in weather forecasting. This superiority is particularly notable in predicting dangerous weather events, such as the tornadoes that devastated the Midwest in early December, killing over 60 people. Human forecasters, leveraging years of experience and nuanced understanding of atmospheric conditions, can identify signs of severe weather that algorithms miss. For instance, Andrew Devanas, a forecaster in Key West, Florida, demonstrated that manual analysis of atmospheric variations could predict waterspouts more accurately than algorithmic models, highlighting the enduring value of human expertise in meteorology.

He said that he “understands that it’s part of how the internet has almost killed journalism. And now journalism is trying to do everything they can to co-opt and maintain their importance.”       Ron Perlman in ‘Don’t Look Up.’ (Niko Tavernise/Netflix)
summaries.summary: Ron Perlman, co-star of Netflix's climate satire "Don’t Look Up," criticized movie critics and attacked Donald Trump and Fox News in a profanity-laced interview with The Independent. Perlman condemned critics for negatively reviewing the film, which also stars Leonardo DiCaprio, Jennifer Lawrence, and Meryl Streep, accusing them of seeking attention without understanding the creative process. "Don’t Look Up" portrays Perlman as a military colonel and has a 55% "rotten" score on Rotten Tomatoes. He also disparaged Fox News hosts as liars and hypocrites and expressed disdain for Trump, highlighting his impeachment and alleged misconducts.

highlights: These can be used to target ads towards a person, placing ads where their eyes are most commonly drawn to, but could also be used for features like full-body tracking allowing them to move every limb of their digital avatar in the metaverse. One patent describes a system for tracking facial expressions through a headset and then serving the users “adapt media content” based on the expressions. This report come shortly after Breitbart News reported that Facebook’s VR division is under investigation by the FTC and multiple U.S. states led by New York.

Clearly, ads play a part in that.” Other patents focus on technology, including eye and face tracking tech that will be collected in a headset using tiny cameras or sensors. These can be used to target ads towards a person, placing ads where their eyes are most commonly drawn to, but could also be used for features like full-body tracking allowing them to move every limb of their digital avatar in the metaverse.
summaries.summary: Facebook (now Meta) has filed patents indicating plans to monetize its metaverse by tracking user behaviors, including eye movements, body positions, and facial expressions. The Financial Times highlights these patents as part of Meta's strategy to generate revenue through hyper-targeted advertising, sponsored content, and a virtual store selling real-world goods. CEO Mark Zuckerberg has committed $10 billion annually over the next decade to develop this virtual world, leveraging Oculus VR technology. Competitors like Apple and Microsoft are also exploring similar virtual spaces. Meta aims for a commerce-led business model, with advertising playing a significant role, utilizing advanced tracking technologies for personalized ad targeting and enhancing user interaction within the metaverse. This development follows scrutiny from the FTC and several U.S. states over privacy concerns.
